EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

The Senate of Mulhus needed not many perÅ¿waÅ¿ions, for they liked not that new gheÅ¿t: But Muncer was too quick for them, for he Å¿o wrought upon the people in a Å¿hort time, that
they put down the MagiÅ¿trates and Å¿et others in their place of their own faction. Not long after they drave the Fryars away, and Å¿eized on their houÅ¿es, of which the beÅ¿t was given to Muncer, who bore himÅ¿elf no more as a meer Preacher, but as a Senator; for he judged of all things out of the Bible andVerbum Å¿criptum, & non Å¿criptum, Thus far PapiÅ¿ts. Divine revelations; and whatÅ¿oever he determined was received as an Oracle; eÅ¿pecially when he preached that all goods muÅ¿t be common;Levellers. and all men free and of equal dignity: An acceptable doctrine in thoÅ¿e parts where the Nobility and Gentry uÅ¿ed their Tenants and VaÅ¿Å¿als like Å¿laves, and oppreÅ¿t them with multitude of impoÅ¿itions and Å¿ervices. No wonder if that new GoÅ¿pel won the meaneÅ¿t Å¿ort, who preÅ¿ently left working, and what they wanted they took by open force from them that had it.

Prevention of bloudÅ¿hed, a wonder in England. At the Å¿ame time in Suevia, and Franconia, 40000 Boors and TradeÅ¿men roÅ¿e up in arms, killed and ranÅ¿ â¢ cked great part of the Nobles, took, pillaged and burnt many Forts and CaÅ¿tles, overthrowing all in their way like a Å¿udden inundation; for when the banks of Authority are once beaten down, nothing can Å¿top the popular fury, till they loÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in their own confuÅ¿ionProbatum, & Å¿ed non approbatum..

Muncer then thought it was time for him to do the like; he layeth up abundance of Ammunition, maketh his Magazine in the Covent of FranciÅ¿cans, caÅ¿teth artillery, raiÅ¿eth a numerous multitude of men, the mean People leaving their loom and their plough, to turn venturers in this holy war.

His chief aÅ¿Å¿ociate was Phifer, one that gave
much credence to dreams and night viÅ¿ions, and among other ViÅ¿ions, would Å¿ay, that he had Å¿een in his dream a great company of Rats in a Stable, and had driven them all away; Which he interpreted as a command from God to take arms and diÅ¿poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s all the Nobility and Gentry: This Phifer was the Å¿touter of the two; for although Muncer was vehement in his Sermons to the people, yet he would not try the hazard of a battel, till all the neighbouring Countries were joyned with him. To which end he Å¿ent divers Letters to the diggers of Mines, of which the County of ManÅ¿field is full, exhorting them Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to fall upon their Princes and cut them off, that Å¿o his Partie in Franconia, which looked but for his call, might have a free paÅ¿Å¿age into Thuringia; But Phifer impatient of delayes, ruÅ¿heth into the Country of Isfield, pillageth CaÅ¿tles and Churches, deÅ¿troyeth many of the Nobles, brings Å¿ome of them bound, and returneth with a great booty; which Å¿ucceÅ¿s raiÅ¿ed the minds of the Boors, and cauÅ¿ed another defection in the County of Mansfield. So Muncer hoping that the Rebellion was univerÅ¿al, taketh his journey from Mulhus, and is preÅ¿ently Å¿upplied with a company of FrankhuÅ¿ians.

But before this Snow-ball could grow by rolling, the Count Mansfield Å¿topt its courÅ¿e; for having raiÅ¿ed in haÅ¿te Å¿ome Companies of HorÅ¿e, he falls upon Muncer, and killeth two hundred of his men, at which the rude unexperienced Boors were Å¿o terrified, that they all fled away to Frankhus, there to expect a greater Å¿upply, though they were men
enough, but (as it Å¿eems) Souldiers few or none. This only skirmiÅ¿h broke the edge of their fury, and gave time to John Elector of Saxonie (newly come to that dignity, by the death of his brother Frederick) and his Uncle George of Saxonie, Philip L â¢ ntgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, and Henry Duke of BrunÅ¿wick, to raiÅ¿e fifteen hundred HorÅ¿e and a few Companies of Infantry.

The Boors were pitched upon a hill by Frankhus, pretty well intrenched within their own Carts, but very ill â¢ rmed, and worÅ¿e diÅ¿ciplined. The Princes, though Å¿lenderly attended, contemned, and pitied together that rude troop, and Å¿ent to offer them impunitie and a general pardon, if they would but yeild the authors of the Å¿edition and return home: But Muncer underÅ¿tood not that GoÅ¿pel, that one man Å¿hould die for the Nation. He falls to preaching, and expounds that Å¿ollicitation of the Princes, as an argument of their weakneÅ¿s and fearfulneÅ¿s; Tels the Boors that he was Å¿ent from God to command and lead them in this action: That their part was to obey like Abraham, who being commanded to kill his Å¿on, went about it, though he was uncertain of the event; That they Å¿hould certainly overthrow both theÅ¿e and all other enemies of God, it being Gods promiÅ¿e that the righteous Å¿hall waÅ¿h his foot in the bloud of the wicked, and that the meek Å¿hall inherit the earth;Governours oppreÅ¿Å¿ions firÅ¿t or laÅ¿t the cauÅ¿e of many miÅ¿chiefs That theÅ¿e Princes were but Tyrants and Theeves, Å¿ucking the bloud of the people, to live at eaÅ¿e and maintain their pride and wantonneÅ¿s; That they maintained the MaÅ¿s, and therefore deÅ¿erved to
be extermined: Then he exhorted them to be valiant in the Lord, and kill every mothers Å¿on of their enemies, for an acceptable Å¿acrifice unto God; aÅ¿Å¿uring them that God himÅ¿elf that cannot lye, had promiÅ¿ed him victory, and commanded him to deÅ¿troy Princes and MagiÅ¿trates, endowing him with Å¿uch Å¿trength that he was able to turn all their bullets back with his coat; Hereupon perceiving a Rain-bow in theThe Devil is Prince of the air, Eph. 2.2. ã in non-Latin alphabet ã . Skie, and turning his eyes towards his Colours, where a Rain-bow was painted; Look up (Å¿aid he) to Heaven; here is for you a joyful Å¿ign of Gods favour, that Rain-bow the very emblem of our Colours; and be Å¿ure that God promiÅ¿eth us that he will be our Standard-bearer and fight for us himÅ¿elf; Come then let's fight valiantly under Gods Standard.

That new piece of impoÅ¿ture made a Å¿trong impreÅ¿Å¿ion in Å¿ome. Yet the Princes drawing near with a warlick march, made a Å¿tronger impreÅ¿Å¿ion of fear in theÅ¿e rude Souldiers, than Muncers revelations and Å¿igns; for the Princes were incenÅ¿ed by a late cruel treachery of Muncer, who had put to death againÅ¿t the Law of Arms and Nations, a hopefull young Gentleman Å¿ent to him to treat of agreement. The Princes began to play with their Ordnance. I cannot Å¿ay toMen of diÅ¿order cannot keep order. break, the ranks of the Boors, for they keep neither Rank nor File, and Å¿carce keep their underÅ¿tanding, for they neither advanced, nor fled, nor put themÅ¿elves in defence, but fell a Å¿inging, Come Holy GhoÅ¿t, expecting that God Å¿hould fight for them from Heaven, according to Muncer's promiÅ¿e: But when their intrenchments
of Carts was broken, and the Princes army came to handy blows, away fled all the boors, Å¿ome one way, Å¿ome another, but the moÅ¿t part to Frankhus; 5000 of them were Å¿lain, Frankhus taken the Å¿ame day, and 300 men taken and executed.

Muncer was found hid at Frankhus, and lying on a bed faigning himÅ¿elf to be one of the Town that had been long Å¿ick of an ague, which his quaking for fear did imitate to the life; but letters being found about him from Albert of Mansfeld, to diÅ¿Å¿wade him from his Å¿editious couÅ¿es, he was known to be Muncer, which yet this lying Prophet denied long.

Being brought before Duke George of Saxony, and the Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, and demanded why he miÅ¿led the Å¿imple people to Å¿edition; He anÅ¿wered that he had done no more than his duty; and that MagiÅ¿trates that receive not the doctrine of the GoÅ¿pel, muÅ¿t be dealt with by Å¿uch wayes: TheÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons of his were confuted by the Rack, where when he cryed out, Duke George told him, Thou Å¿uffereÅ¿t now Muncer; but think how many poor people have Å¿uffered by thee this day; At which Muncer laughed aloud and Å¿aid, Why, they would have it Å¿o, meaning that the people loved to be cozened and miÅ¿led, and that nothing could win their hearts but Å¿edition.

Shortly after Phifer and other heads of the rebellion were executed at Mulhus, and Muncer a while after, who Å¿hewed a great deal of dejection and perturbation in his end, and could not Å¿o much
as make confeÅ¿Å¿ion of his Faith, with much ado could he Å¿peak after the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick who taught him what he Å¿hould Å¿ay; Yet when he was ready to be executed, heThe magiÅ¿trates Å¿word by Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ing may do good; Babylons priÅ¿on made ManaÅ¿Å¿eh fitter for a Throne. acknowledged his errour openly, and made an exhortation to the Princes and Nobles, to uÅ¿e their Å¿ubjects and vaÅ¿Å¿als with more moderation; which if they did, the people would break no more into Å¿uch rebellions and outrages; he deÅ¿ired them diligently to read the book of Kings, there to learn their duty, and Gods judgements againÅ¿t unjuÅ¿tice and oppreÅ¿Å¿ion. He was beheaded, and his head Å¿et on a high pole in the fields.

In the mean while Luther, becauÅ¿e he was defamed by the PapiÅ¿ts, as the author or occaÅ¿ion of thoÅ¿e troubles, was Å¿ending godly exhortations over all Germany, to exhort the commons to peace and obedience to their Superiours, and rather to Å¿uffer for righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s, then defend the Truth with unrighteouÅ¿neÅ¿s; and that this was the Devils cunning to raiÅ¿e Å¿edition by falÅ¿e brethren, to bring the Truth of God into hatred and obloquie.

And to the commons of Suevia, that had been up in armes before Muncer, and continued Å¿till in rebellion, he writ a grave admonition, repreÅ¿enting that although they were oppreÅ¿t by their Princes, who therefore deÅ¿erved to be puniÅ¿ht, yet it belonged not to them to do the execution;The Judge muÅ¿t hang a Thief; and he lawfully commiÅ¿Å¿ioned. nota benÃ¨. That they muÅ¿t not believe the Sermons of every preacher; for Satan (Å¿aith he) under colour of the GoÅ¿pel hath in theÅ¿e times raiÅ¿ed many Å¿editious and bloudy teachers; You are oppreÅ¿t by
your Superiours that take your eÅ¿tates from you, that do unjuÅ¿tly; but you do more unjuÅ¿tly to take that JuriÅ¿diction from them which is none of yours; And whereas they take but few things from you by exactions and too great burdens, you take all from them when you take away their authority: Is this obeying ChriÅ¿t who com â¢ ands us not to reÅ¿iÅ¿t evill, but to him that Å¿triketh us on the one cheek to turn the other, and let him that will take our Coate, to take our Cloak alÅ¿o? Nay, it is the duty of ChriÅ¿tians to Å¿uffer and undergo the CroÅ¿s, not to reÅ¿iÅ¿t and Å¿eek revenge and Å¿mite with the Å¿word; When Peter would fight to Å¿ave his MaÅ¿ter, a lawfull defence if ever was any, He bids him not to Å¿trike with the Å¿word, becauÅ¿e that Å¿triking was oppoÅ¿ing the MagiÅ¿trate for a private revenge; and to Å¿uch oppoÅ¿ers of the MagiÅ¿trate that Sentence belongeth, They that Å¿trike with the Å¿word, Å¿hall periÅ¿h with the Å¿word: But I perceive the Devils plot, that Å¿ince he could not deÅ¿troy me by the Pope, he Å¿eeks to undo me by theÅ¿e violent bloud-thirÅ¿ty preachers:Any way Å¿o it be done, pleaÅ¿es him. And do you take heed of them, for they caÅ¿t you headlong into a precipice, that they may riÅ¿e by your fall, and get honors and dignities with your perill.

That Suevian Rebellion was Å¿oon after Å¿uppreÅ¿t, partly by the vigorous oppoÅ¿ition of the Princes, partly by their own wearineÅ¿s and diÅ¿order, the limbs of that faction dropping off here and there, like a rotten carkaÅ¿e that can no longer hang together. Malum malum deÅ¿truit. Snared in the work of his own hand, PÅ¿al. 9.16.

Muncer and his aÅ¿Å¿ociates being puniÅ¿ht, CaroloÅ¿tadius was not far from the like danger; for having left Wittemberg where he feared Luther, he kept conventicles in Saxony, aÅ¿Å¿ociating himÅ¿elf with frantick men that boaÅ¿ted of ViÅ¿ions, and Colloquies with God, and a particular Å¿pirit; There alÅ¿o he writ a bitter book againÅ¿t Luther, and againÅ¿t his own Prince, for which miÅ¿demeanours he was Å¿ought to be executed with Muncer's complices; In that extreamity he called upon Luther's help, whom he had Å¿o much provoked, and was Å¿aved by his interceÅ¿Å¿ion.Heroick.

div.head: CHAP. III. The growth of AnabaptiÅ¿me, The Tragical diÅ¿orders committed at MunÅ¿ter.
div.p:
THE root and branch of fanatical factions Å¿eemed then to be cut off, but the Å¿eeds remained, and brought forth many new twigs of the Å¿ame kinde: PreÅ¿ently after Muncer, one of greater learning and parts, began to preach the Å¿ame doctrine at Strasburg, and was impriÅ¿oned for it by the Rulers of the City; his name was Melchior Hopman: Anno 1527. And Å¿carce two years after Muncer, Germany was fullIll weeds grow apace. of AnabaptiÅ¿ts; A new name then, but in effect the old Å¿ect of Muncer, with Å¿ome additions.There is a reÅ¿urrection of error as well as of truth. They denyed the incarnation of ChriÅ¿t in the holy Virgins womb, condemned the
BaptiÅ¿me of Children, and re-baptized themÅ¿elves, and all that embraced their Å¿ect: They would not allow ChriÅ¿tians to recover their own by Law, nor to take an Oath, nor bear the Office of MagiÅ¿trate, and they pulled down MagiÅ¿trates by way of fact where they had Å¿trength, and gave the power of the Å¿word to their MiniÅ¿ters and Prophets, who decided all difference, and judged of all caÅ¿es by Scripture, and undertook to kill all the Princes of the World, and cut off all the ungodly with another Å¿word than that of the Spirit: They taught that in their Church all were holy, that none can be Å¿ â¢ ved that will not make his private goods common, that it is lawfull to have many wives, that all learning is prophane, and that mean ignorant men are the fitteÅ¿t to expound Scripture, that there muÅ¿t be no ordinary calling in the Church, but every one may Å¿peak as he is inÅ¿pired by the Holy GhoÅ¿t; that ChriÅ¿t muÅ¿t reign over all the World, and therefore all other Kings and Princes, and their adherents muÅ¿t be Å¿lain, till there be none left to reign but ChriÅ¿t; and what they taught they went really about to practiÅ¿e.

Melchior Hopman being kept priÅ¿oner at Strasburg, and his Sect Å¿everly repreÅ¿t by the wiÅ¿e MagiÅ¿trate; that crew diÅ¿perÅ¿ed it Å¿elf in WeÅ¿tphalia, FriÅ¿e, Holland, and moÅ¿t part of the Low Countreys, where they got a very great party, yet among the common Å¿ort of people onely. Lambertus HertenÅ¿ius one of my Authors affirmeth confidently, that among that numerous rabble of Å¿editious people, not one was found that ever was a Schollar, and
very few that could read or write. When they were confuted by reaÅ¿ons or teÅ¿timonies of Scripture, their anÅ¿wer was, that the Spirit taught them otherwiÅ¿e, and that the Spirit bloweth where he liÅ¿teth, and doth not inÅ¿pire every one.

TheÅ¿e fancies were increaÅ¿ed by one George of Leyden, with many groÅ¿s and monÅ¿trous Additions: The Å¿ect by his Å¿eduction in Å¿hort time grew Å¿o Å¿trong, as to deÅ¿piÅ¿e all Rule, all Judges, and all Courts, and chuÅ¿e private Rulers among themÅ¿elves, who determined of all cauÅ¿es, and Å¿ate upon life and death.

But their rage could not keep long at home; They would Å¿ometimes ruÅ¿h out of Cities in great troops, and ranÅ¿ack Convents and Rich mens houÅ¿es, taking for their warrant the example of the IÅ¿raelites, that took the Å¿poyl of the Egyptians: Yet in theÅ¿e incurÅ¿ions they made ConÅ¿cience at the firÅ¿t to enter into any Temple of thoÅ¿e that were not re-baptized, but made no conÅ¿cience to lye with their wives as left for a prey to the godly.

This was their preparation for the day of Judgement, about which they had many revelations: One of their Prophets proclaimed that within three days the laÅ¿t judgment Å¿hould comedoomsday Sedgw. ; This made many of them to leave their houÅ¿es, and get up into high trees there to expect the Comming of ChriÅ¿t; but having expected three days faÅ¿ting, they returned faint and weak, and met with another Judgment at home; for the MagiÅ¿trate inquired after the Authors and promoters of that deluÅ¿ion, and puniÅ¿hed them.

Of all Cities of the Low-Countries, AmÅ¿terdam was moÅ¿t peÅ¿tered with that Å¿ect, the great concourÅ¿e and traffick giving them fair opportunity to reÅ¿ort to that famous place: Where being many times repreÅ¿t with fines and impriÅ¿onments and wholeÅ¿ome Å¿everity, they would diÅ¿perÅ¿e themÅ¿elves over the Country, filling all with clamour, Å¿cattering papers in the high ways, threatning ruine and deÅ¿truction to all that would not adhere to them, and leave lands and houÅ¿es to come out of Babylon; for Babylon they would overthrow; and within the circuit of Babylon, they included all MagiÅ¿tracy and Civil Government, and all wealth and greatneÅ¿s; A great quarrel they had with the Babylonian Gold.

But the whole World was little enough for their ambition. It was their Å¿erious intent to make themÅ¿elves maÅ¿ters of the World, which they both profeÅ¿Å¿ed and attempted, beginning their Empire at MunÅ¿ter in WeÅ¿tphalia.

It grieveth me to Å¿ay that in MunÅ¿ter, truth made way for error: For in the year 1532, one Bernard Rotman came to S. Maurice Church hard by MunÅ¿ter, where he preached good doctrine and converted many, Å¿o that the people would have him admitted into the City; Which the PapiÅ¿ts fearing, gave him a Å¿umme of Money, upon condition he Å¿hould go to Å¿ome other place, which he did, and abÅ¿ented himÅ¿elf for Å¿ome months, in which time he improved his gifts and learning, and returned again better furniÅ¿ht to encounter the adverÅ¿ary.

Being received at Saint Maurice with greater applauÅ¿e than before, Å¿ome Citizens of the beÅ¿t Å¿ort brought him into the City, and becauÅ¿e the Church doors were Å¿hut againÅ¿t him they made him a Pulpit in the Church-yard, and Å¿hortly after told the PapiÅ¿ts, that if they would not open the door of Å¿ome Church, they would open it themÅ¿elves. Rotman Å¿eeing the progreÅ¿s of the Reformation, Å¿ends to HaÅ¿Å¿e for Å¿ome help, and they Å¿ent to him two Divines of Marpurg; With theÅ¿e by the counÅ¿el and authority of the beÅ¿t in the Town, he challenged PapiÅ¿ts in diÅ¿pute, and preÅ¿ented thirty Articles of PapiÅ¿tical errours to the Senate, offering to prove that they were contrary to holy Scripture: The Senate Å¿ends for the Clergy of the City, and requireth them that Å¿ince they had always profeÅ¿t that their doctrine was grounded upon holy Writ, they would now make it good: The Clergy finding themÅ¿elves unexpectedly put to it, anÅ¿wered plainly that it was more than they could, and that they were Å¿ure they had a good intention, though there might be ignorance and errour in their profeÅ¿Å¿ionIgnorantia mater devotionis.: Whereupon the Senate interdicted them to teach the People any more, and gave their places to the new teachers that had detected the impoÅ¿tures of the old.

The expulÅ¿ed Clergy retire to their BiÅ¿hop and Prince, (for the BiÅ¿hop of MunÅ¿ter is Prince of the City.) The then BiÅ¿hop was Count Francis Waldeck, to whom Frederick ArchbiÅ¿hop of Collen had lately yeilded the place. The BiÅ¿hop preÅ¿ently Å¿tops all the paÅ¿Å¿ages of Victuals to the City, and
raiÅ¿eth Å¿ome forces to compel the Citizens to reÅ¿tore all things in the former State. But the Citizens by a nigt enterprize, took his beÅ¿t men, and the richeÅ¿t of the PopiÅ¿h party lying in a little Town, whence the BiÅ¿hop was gone the day before: This gave occaÅ¿ion to parley and a CompoÅ¿ition, by the mediation of the Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, wherein it was agreed upon,This agreement was made Feb. 14. 1538. th â¢ t Å¿ix Churches Å¿hould be given to the Reformed party, and that the Cathedral Å¿hould remain as it was before.

Hitherto all was well, if it could have Å¿taid there; But before the Å¿winge of the former commotion was well Å¿taid, there comes to the Town in an ill hour, a peÅ¿tilent AnabaptiÅ¿t, a Taylor of Leyden, Joh â¢ Becold, better known by the name of John of Leyden: This man begins to confer with MiniÅ¿ters and People, about the BaptiÅ¿m of Children, maintaining it to be unlawful, Å¿educing many, and Å¿owring the new Lump of that Church with the Leaven of his perverÅ¿s doctrine: with him or preÅ¿ently after him came a very great multitude of his fraternity, moÅ¿t of them Hollanders. TheÅ¿e keeping conventicles in the night, got a great party in the City, and incenÅ¿ed one another with deÅ¿perate reÅ¿olutions. They had with them one Herman Strapeda, brought up under Henry Rell, who had been lately executed at Æ²trecht, for preaching AnabaptiÅ¿m and Å¿edition; At the feet of that Gamaliel, one may think what doctrine he had learned: This man they got to be choÅ¿en colleague to Rotman, before his hereÅ¿ie was known; but he made it known preÅ¿ently preaching openly againÅ¿t
the BaptiÅ¿m of children, and none more eager to oppoÅ¿e him than Rotman: The MagiÅ¿trates and people not yet infected with that new doctrine, feeling Å¿o much diÅ¿traction ariÅ¿ing among themÅ¿elves, commanded the Forreiners and Sectaries to go out of the City; but they went out at one gate, and came in again at the other, Å¿aying, that they muÅ¿t not deÅ¿ert Gods cauÅ¿e, but do the work which God had given them to do: The Senate to prevent a Å¿edition, appointed the Evangelicks and the AnabaptiÅ¿ts to meet in a publick Conference; and there Rotman betrayed the good cauÅ¿e, and diÅ¿puted contrary to his preaching, condemning the baptiÅ¿m of children as impious and execrable; But he was Å¿o well oppoÅ¿ed by a worthy Divine Hermannus BaÅ¿ilius, that the Senate was Å¿atisfied, and concluded for the Truth, and the Teachers AnabaptiÅ¿ts were Å¿entenced to be baniÅ¿hed: Who when they alleadged that they could not Å¿ â¢ fely travel through the BiÅ¿hops dominions, the Senate obtained a Å¿afe conduct for them, & g â¢ ve them mony for their journey. But they being reÅ¿olved before not to go away, lay lurking among their Sectaries, which increaÅ¿ed Å¿o faÅ¿t, (the mean people of the Town being Å¿educed every day, and Å¿trangers flocking to the Town continually in great troops) that the MagiÅ¿trates fearing leÅ¿t the AnabaptiÅ¿ts Å¿hould drive the Evangelicks out of their Churches, kept all the Churches Å¿hut up but one.

In this diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed caÅ¿e of their Church and State, the Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ent them at the requeÅ¿t of the Senate, two Divines, Theodoricus Fabritius,
and Johannes MelÅ¿ingerus; But the laÅ¿t Å¿eeing the deplorable face of buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es in that place, and fearing his own danger, returned home: Fabritius remained, and among Å¿o much contradiction diÅ¿charged the part of a worthy champion of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, till the AnabaptiÅ¿ts having got the upper hand, thruÅ¿t him and all the Evangelicks out of the City. And to Å¿et a bound to the unlimited extravagancie of the AnabaptiÅ¿tical Å¿pirit, he compoÅ¿ed a book of Common-prayers, with the Form of adminiÅ¿tring the Sacraments and performing other EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical duties, and it was publiÅ¿hed by the authority of the Senate.

There was alÅ¿o another worthy Divine, Peter Wirtem, who having been Å¿ilenced by the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, was now by the Senate and people allowed to preach again: But he was no Preacher for the new brethren; they turned him out of office preÅ¿ently, at the inÅ¿tigation of Rotman, who Å¿oon after provoked Fabritius and his colleagues to diÅ¿pute: Fabritius accepted the challenge, and the Senate appointed a Conference, naming Å¿ome learned and good men to be the Umpires; But Rotman and his brethren fearing the Touch, began to find exceptions and deviÅ¿e Å¿hifts to avoid the diÅ¿pute, whereby they loÅ¿t much credit among the people.

To wipe off that Å¿tain, they took a more compendious courÅ¿e: One of them faining himÅ¿elf Å¿eized with a Prophetical Å¿pirit ran through theNo new thing. City, crying, Repent, and be baptized again, elÅ¿e the wrath of God will fall upon you: This
Å¿tirred the people, and many ran alÅ¿o with him, crying the Å¿ â¢ me words: Many of the Å¿impler Å¿ort were reb â¢ ptized for fear of the wrath of God, and many more for fear of the wrath of menIntereÅ¿t their God.: For this crying and running through the Å¿treets, ended in ranÅ¿ â¢ cking the beÅ¿t houÅ¿es, and laying violent hands on the owners. Then many that lay hid before, came forth, and ruÅ¿hed into the Market place, crying out, that all that were not rebaptized muÅ¿t be killed preÅ¿ently, as Ungodly and Heathen; And Å¿eizing upon the Town-HouÅ¿e and the weapons therein, they began to domineer as in a conquered place.

The Evangeliques on the other Å¿ide gathered themÅ¿elves in a place called Overwater, and took many of their enemies, and both the Å¿ides were fortifying the places where they Å¿tood: Three d â¢ ys they Å¿tood thus without doing any great harm one to the other, till giving hoÅ¿tages on both Å¿ides, they fell to a compoÅ¿ition; That every one Å¿hould enjoy the freedom of his Religion, and all Å¿hould go home and live in pe â¢ ce. This tumult was towards the end of Decemb. 1533.

Anno 1534.But this compoÅ¿ition gave but time to the AnabaptiÅ¿ts to Å¿trengthen their party; for Rotman and Bernard Knipperdoling, the moÅ¿t Å¿tirring of that faction, Å¿ent letters to the Towns of OÅ¿nburg, WeÅ¿el, CorÅ¿weld and Warendorp, of which the tenour was, that God had Å¿ent an holy ProphetThey that have leaÅ¿t, oft pretend moÅ¿t. to MunÅ¿ter, who Å¿pake wonders, and Å¿hewed the right way to Salvation: That if they would leave their houÅ¿es and come to MunÅ¿ter in all haÅ¿te, they

TheÅ¿e fair promiÅ¿es drew all the Å¿cum of the neighbouring Towns to MunÅ¿ter, the pooreÅ¿t and idleÅ¿t Å¿ort liking that Religion well, that maketh all men alike and all goods common, and puts down thoÅ¿e Laws and MagiÅ¿trates that refrained their licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s. In a Å¿hort time the City was full of Å¿trangers and vagrants th â¢ t looked upon the City as a Land of PromiÅ¿e, where they muÅ¿t take a new plantation, and expulÅ¿e the Canaanites. The AnabaptiÅ¿ts Å¿eeing themÅ¿elves Å¿trong, ran to Saint Maurice Church and burnt it with all the houÅ¿es about it, pillaged all the Churches, defaced the Cathedral, depopulated the Convents and Colledges, and burnt a fair great Library belonging to the Fryers; And for the final exploit, drove all the Evangeliques out of the City, but Å¿ome few (whom they miÅ¿took for AnabaptiÅ¿ts) crying, Get hence all ye wicked, elÅ¿e you Å¿hall all be Å¿lain. In this baniÅ¿hment the grieved Citizens Å¿uffered double perÅ¿ecution; for being turned out bare by the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, they were taken by the BiÅ¿hopIn extremis nulla Å¿alus., who the day before had encamped before the City,
and by him uÅ¿ed as enemies: Å¿ome were in danger to have loÅ¿t their heads, as the worthy Divine Peter Wirtem, who was Å¿aved by the mediation of the Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿en. And now the AnabaptiÅ¿ts being MaÅ¿ters of the City, began to order their new State; for though they were enemies to all Superiority and Order, yet neceÅ¿Å¿ity and Nature it Å¿elf forced them to elect Å¿ome Superiours of their own. They made two ConÅ¿uls, Knipperdolling and Kippenbrok, and twenty two Senators or Aldermen, that had the Civil power. The Prophets were to rule matters of Religion, under which name they governed Church and Common-wealth;In ordine ad Å¿piritualia. Bell. for all civil matters were brought within the compaÅ¿s of Religion and ConÅ¿cience, and whatÅ¿oever a Prophet Å¿aid to be revealed unto him, paÅ¿t for Law.

The moÅ¿t famous of theÅ¿e Prophets was John Matthias, a Baker of Harlem, who was in effect a perpetual Dictator in MunÅ¿ter, that made Laws and changed them after his pleaÅ¿ure: By him was the foreÅ¿aid Order made; His chief adjunct was John of Leyden, and the next Bern. Knipperdolling. By a revelation of John Matthias, an order was made upon pain of death, that all the gold and Å¿ilver and moveable goods of the Town Å¿hould be brought to the common Stock, for which they appointed a publick houÅ¿e: The order was obeyed, more for fear then conÅ¿cience; for two maidsThe Devil knows how to make good uÅ¿e of bad women. PropheteÅ¿Å¿es,
took upon them to find out the fraud, and the Å¿everal houÅ¿es were Å¿earched by a Deacon; To th â¢ t common Stock were brought all the goods of thoÅ¿e that were driven out of the City.

With that common Stock they kept four great Ordinaries in the four quarters of the Town, where all fed in common, none being allowed to diet at home, unleÅ¿s he were Å¿ick: Plenty of proviÅ¿ion they had, and they husbanded it very ill, feaÅ¿ting every day till the BiÅ¿hop that beÅ¿ieged them, began to cut off their victuals, and then they Å¿tinted themÅ¿elves, but with too large a Å¿tint, which was to have change of meat every third day, one day freÅ¿h meat, the other day hung meat and bacon, and the third day milk, butter and cheeÅ¿e.

I read of no great feats of arms in this Å¿iege. Once only the BiÅ¿hop received a notable repulÅ¿e by John Matthias, who w â¢ s a General â¢ s well as a Prophet; With eaÅ¿ie labour he had Å¿o fortified the Town, which is moÅ¿t Å¿trong by Nature, that he had made it impregnable, Å¿o that the BiÅ¿hop deÅ¿p â¢ iring to take it by force, went about to take it by famine. The Prophets then neglecting the BiÅ¿hop, converted their care to the Å¿piritual government; and commanded that none Å¿hould keep any book but Scripture: So all the books that could be found, but Bibles,The Bible much made o â¢ moÅ¿t abuÅ¿ed. were brought to a publique place and a bonfire made of them.

From executing of books they fell to executing
of perÅ¿ons;Seducers grow worÅ¿e & worÅ¿e. Hubert Truteling a Black-Å¿mith, Å¿eeing Joh. Matthias paÅ¿s by, Å¿aid, Here goeth a Å¿hittenWe have Å¿een Å¿hitten Quakers, one coming into the publike AÅ¿Å¿embly on the L. day naked, and Å¿hitten up to the elbows. Prophet; For this offence he was brought to the Congregation and condemned to death: John Matthias would himÅ¿elf be the executioner, and wounded him with an Halbert; the wound being not mortal, he brings him to another place and Å¿hoots him thorow with a piÅ¿toll, then taking compaÅ¿Å¿ion on him, he pardons him, Å¿aying, that God was appeaÅ¿ed towards him, and that he had a revelation that the man Å¿hould not die of this, yet the poor man died a few days after.

To make amends for his falÅ¿e propheÅ¿ie, He runs in a mad mood over all the City, bearing a Pike, crying, that God the Father had commanded him to drive the enemy back from the City, and Å¿o ruÅ¿hed alone into the enemies camp, without fear and wit,Every way mad. and was there killed.

John Matthias being dead, John of Leyden comforteth the people, Å¿aying, that he knew long before by revelation that John Matthias was to die that death, & that himÅ¿elf Å¿hould marry his wifePretend the Spirit, intend the FleÅ¿h., as he did Å¿hortly after, though he had one before; but this was one of Å¿ingular beauty, able to make a luÅ¿ty young Prophet to Å¿et up the doctrine of Polygamy.

But he fell to other work before he Å¿tirred that point; Knipperdolling came out wth a revelation, that they that were in high places Å¿hould be brought down to the loweÅ¿t; & they that were in the loweÅ¿t, raiÅ¿ed to the higheÅ¿tThey will turn all upÅ¿ide down.. But John of Leyden met him in his own kind with another revelation, that Å¿ince it was Gods pleaÅ¿ure that thoÅ¿e that were in the higheÅ¿t
places Å¿hould be brought down to the loweÅ¿t, he was Å¿ent from God to put him down from the place of ConÅ¿ul, & make him the Hang-man, and to that purpoÅ¿e he gave him from God the Å¿word of juÅ¿tice.

But there was need of more revelations for that great work of alteration of the government; John of Leyden was led by his prophetical Å¿pirit upon the City walls, where he put off his clothes, and ranThe old trade naked through the City, crying, The King of Sion is come, The King of Sion is come. Then returning home, he falls into a deep prophetical Å¿leep, andFilthy dreamers Jude 8. ã in non-Latin alphabet ã . dreams three days and three nights together: Being awaked, he comes forth and Å¿peaketh never a word, but calleteth by Å¿igns for a Table-book, like Zechariah. There he Å¿ets down twelve men, all Coblers, Tinkers, Smiths, and mean TradeÅ¿men, but one that was a Gentleman of MunÅ¿ter; to theÅ¿e he aÅ¿Å¿igneth the government of the Common-wealth, putting down the order Å¿et up by John Matthias, and affirming that this was the FathersYou are of your father the Devil. good will. In that paper alÅ¿o he writeth Å¿ome concluÅ¿ions, which he chargeth the preachers to teach the people; Or elÅ¿e he would have them ratified by the Congregation without the Preachers: The Å¿um of all was, that a man is not tied to one wife, but that he mayThis is Å¿piritually the clean contrary way. marry as many as he pleaÅ¿eth. And when moÅ¿t of his Doctors would not approve of that monÅ¿trous paradox, he citeth them before his twelve MagiÅ¿trates, and there he recovered his tongue, keeping a great clamor, throwing down his cloths upon the ground, and the new TeÅ¿tament upon them, and Å¿wearing by that holy book, that the doctrine which he had

To teÅ¿tifie his evidence of Å¿pirit â¢ nd power, he commanded the firÅ¿t oppoÅ¿er of that new GoÅ¿pel to be beheaded, which was done preÅ¿ently.

For three days together there was preaching concerning matrimony, for the confirmation of that opinion; But the beÅ¿t confirmation was his practice; for preÅ¿ently he married three wives, one of which was the relict of that grand Prophet Joh. Matthias, by whom Å¿he was with child; and married again and again, till he had fifteen wives. Many followed his example, and it began to be a matter of great praiÅ¿e to multiply wives.

This Å¿eemeth to have been his firÅ¿t motive to broach that doctrine; A Souldier of the BiÅ¿hops that had changed party, and was harboured where John of Leyden lay, obÅ¿erved in the night, that this holy Prophet left his bed, and went to the maids bedDefiling the fleÅ¿h. Jude 8. ã in non-Latin alphabet ã .: John of Leyden Å¿eeing himÅ¿elf diÅ¿covered, in the morning called the Souldier aÅ¿ide, and gave him gold, deÅ¿iring him to keep his counÅ¿el: But after miÅ¿truÅ¿ting the Souldiers tongue, he thought it Å¿afer to countenance the fact by aFaÅ¿hioning their doctrine to practiÅ¿e a new light. publick doctrine.

This doctrine then was readily embraced by thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e age and temper was apteÅ¿t to conÅ¿ult with fleÅ¿h and blood; None refraining himÅ¿elf from multiplication of wives for want or covetouÅ¿neÅ¿s, for their wives were kept upon the common-Stock. Neither did they keep any face of Order or any Å¿hew of modeÅ¿ty in thoÅ¿e marriages; for preÅ¿ently
after the receiving of that Law, the brethren ran to the hanÅ¿omeÅ¿t women of the City, Å¿triving who Å¿hould be Å¿erved firÅ¿t, and lay with them without any form of contract, Å¿o that within few days there was not one woman of 14. years of age but was violated

But thoÅ¿e of the City that yet had Å¿ome remnant of Å¿ound mind, being extreamly grieved with diÅ¿order, and groaning under that foul tyranny, made a party, and laid hold of John of Leyden & Knipperdolling and all the Prophets; which coming to the ears of the frantick rabble of people, which made the greateÅ¿t number, they took arms and reÅ¿cued the Prophets, and killed fifty of their adverÅ¿aries, moÅ¿t of them in cold blood, and with Å¿everal kinds of deviÅ¿ed crueltiesSeducers cruel., John of Leyden encouraging the murtherers, and crying, that he that would do God Å¿ervice Å¿hould give the firÅ¿t blow.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Continuation of the Å¿iege of MunÅ¿ter, The reign of John of Leyden, The taking of MunÅ¿ter, The deÅ¿erved puniÅ¿hment of the Rebels.
div.p:
VVHile they were thus wiving and Å¿triving in MunÅ¿ter, the BiÅ¿hop had fair play, if he could have husbanded the occaÅ¿ion. Some weak attempts he made, with ill Å¿ucceÅ¿s, and having till then born the charges of the warr alone, he was afterwards aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with men and mony by Herman ArchbiÅ¿hop of Colen, and John Prince of Cleves, and asked Å¿uccour of all the Cities of the Rhyne, about
which demand there was a meeting appointed to be held at Coblents, Decemb. 13. 1534.

This long delay gave time to John of Leyden to project new deÅ¿igns; He declared that the Spirit of PropheÅ¿ie was retired from him, and repoÅ¿ed upon John TuÅ¿cocurer a GoldÅ¿mith of Warendorp; And this new Prophet having called the Congregation together, declared that it was the will of the heavenly Father that John of Leyden Å¿hould beHe wil ceaÅ¿e to be a Prophet that he may be King. King of the UniverÅ¿e; And that with mighty Armies he Å¿hould kill all Kings and Princes, and deÅ¿troy all the ungodly, and Å¿ave the people that love righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s, and that he muÅ¿t poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s the Kingdom of his Father David, till the time come that he muÅ¿t deliver the Kingdom to his FatherThe h â¢ ight of blaÅ¿phemy.; And that all the ungodly being killed, the godly Å¿hould reign in the World. Whereupon John of Leyden fell on his knees, and lifting up his hands to heaven, Å¿aid, Men and brethren, Å¿o much I knew long ago, but I would not reveal it; Now God hath made choice of another to bear witneÅ¿s to that truth. Then Å¿aid TuÅ¿cocurer again, Thus Å¿aith the Lord, As I Å¿et Saul to be King in IÅ¿rael, and after him David taken from the Sheep-fold, Å¿o I have Å¿et John Becold my Prophet to be King in Sion: And when the Senate refuÅ¿ed that propheÅ¿ie, the Prophet refuÅ¿ed the Senate, and appealed to the Congregation, Å¿ â¢ ying, Give ear IÅ¿rael, Thou Å¿halt abrogate thy MagiÅ¿trates, and put down thy Preachers, and inÅ¿tead of them eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h 12 Å¿imple menSimple men Å¿educed, great agents for Satan. without any learning; them thou Å¿halt command that they read my word unto my people, and without any help but my Å¿pirit, expound it;
into them will I pour the Å¿pirit of wiÅ¿dom and underÅ¿tanding. Then giving a Å¿word to of John of Leyden, And to thee (Å¿aith he) Father Becold, the Father giveth this Å¿word, and calleth thee not only to be King in Sion, but over all the World, and to extend thine Empire unto the ends of the earth.
This oracle was followed with great Å¿houtings and acclamations of the people, crying, God Å¿ave the King, and preÅ¿ently he was brought to S. Lamberts Church-yard, and there again proclaimed K.

There the new King created four CounÅ¿ellors of State, the chief whereof was one Gerard a Bookbinder, one Talbeck he made Lord Steward of his houÅ¿hold, Gerard Kippenbrok TreaÅ¿urer of his Plate and Jewels, Knipperdolling Governor of the City, and appointed twelve Archers of his Guard.

This Taylor King preÅ¿ently made uÅ¿e of his skill to make himÅ¿elf fine in clothes. He tranÅ¿lated the copes and carpets of the Churches & convents, into dublets and breeches, and cloaks, which Å¿et off his MajeÅ¿ty all in gold and Å¿ilver. His horÅ¿es wore a Å¿uitable livery, richly harneÅ¿Å¿ed with golden and Å¿ilver Saddles and footcloths; he had great change of rich apparel, in which he appeared abroad, having his chief Officers aid CounÅ¿ellors riding before him in great State. Next to him rid two young men richly attired, the one carrying a naked Å¿word with a golden hilt, Å¿et with precious Å¿tones, the other carried a Bible and a triple Crown of gold, of exquiÅ¿ite work, glittering with diamonds. HimÅ¿elf wore a great chain of gold about his neck, like a Coller of Å¿ome noble Order, with a golden Globe
having a golden Sword thorough it, hanging at the chain, with this Motto about the Globe, Rex juÅ¿titiae hujus mundi, the King of RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿s of this world. After him followed fifty PenÅ¿ioners clad with parti-coloured garments of aÅ¿h-colour and graÅ¿s-green, white caps, and golden rings on every finger, making the aÅ¿h-colour an emblem of mortification, the graÅ¿s-green of regeneration, the white caps of innocencie, the golden rings of charity: but among theÅ¿e prophetical riddles, he ordered his Court with Å¿o much State, and Å¿o diÅ¿poÅ¿ed his Officers, that if he had been a King born, he could have done it no better. So much all his adverÅ¿aries acknowledge.

In that Royal array he Å¿hewed himÅ¿elf three times a week in publick, and went up to a high Throne Å¿et up with great magnificence: Under him Å¿ate Knipperdolling Governour of the City; and lower, his four great CounÅ¿ellors of State. In that Court he he judged of all controverÅ¿ies, moÅ¿t of which were about divorces, for by his new orders any man that was weary of his wife might take another, & as many more as he liÅ¿ted; which could not but multiply Å¿uits, and give work to the new King, and his CounÅ¿ellors, and Prophets.

In that Court Knipperdolling would ever come out with Å¿ome Bedlam rapture: Once he fell flat to the ground, and creeping upon his hands and feet, he went to Å¿everal perÅ¿ons of the AÅ¿Å¿embly, and blowing them in the mouth Å¿aid, The Father hath Å¿anctified thee, receive the holy GhoÅ¿t; Another time he fell a dancing, Å¿aying, So I danc't once with
my little harlot, and now the heavenly Father hath commanded me that I Å¿hould dance Å¿o in the Kings preÅ¿ence: Another time before the King came, he Å¿ate in his chair of MajeÅ¿ty, and there propheÅ¿ied that he Å¿hould die and riÅ¿e again, and that then the eys of the blind Å¿hould be open; But the King comming, Å¿hewed him that the Å¿pirits of the Prophets muÅ¿t be Å¿ubject unto the Prophets, for he pulled him down and committed him to the Jail for three days.

This jolly Taylor having thus Å¿titched up a kingdom in haÅ¿te, turned his Å¿erious care to go thorow Å¿titch with it: For that there was need of Å¿upply to to remove the BiÅ¿hop that hindered his work; And becauÅ¿e all Å¿hould be done in a Prophetical way, TuiÅ¿cocurer, his chief agent, came to him (as it Å¿eems by his appointment) one day as he was Å¿itting in his Throne with more than ordinary MajeÅ¿ty, and told him, King John, the GoÅ¿pel muÅ¿t be renewed by thee; Thus Å¿aith the Lord God, Go and Å¿ay to the King of Sion, that he prepare my holy Supper in the Church-yard of the great Church, and that he chuÅ¿e Teachers of my word, to Å¿end into the four Cuarters of the World, to teach all men the ways of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s, and bring them by the Å¿pirit of their mouth into my Sheepfold: Å¿o a publick Communion was celebrated, but they made it a full meal; A great feaÅ¿t (r) it was, both for the perÅ¿ons and the meat, for they were above four thouÅ¿and men, and had three courÅ¿es: But between theÅ¿e courÅ¿es, there was a Å¿oul entercourÅ¿e, for the King accuÅ¿ed a man of TreaÅ¿on, and cut off his head with his own
hand, and returned merry to Å¿upper; Then with his bloody hand he took upon him to adminiÅ¿ter the body and blood of ChriÅ¿t
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã ., aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with the Queen (Å¿ometime John Matthias his wife) who then did the office of the MiniÅ¿ter or Deacon, and adminiÅ¿tred the CommunionQuis talia fando temperet a lachrymis!; the like did the principal officers of the State, Å¿aying, Take this and announce the Lords death.

After Å¿upper, the King asked the whole Congregation, whether they were all heartily diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to do Gods Will, and to Å¿uffer and die for the faith; to which the people anÅ¿wered with one voice that they were all in that mind, then TuiÅ¿cocurer aroÅ¿e and Å¿aid, Thus Å¿aith the Lord, chuÅ¿e men among my people, to Å¿end into the 4 quarters of the world,Where will they Å¿top. to do great wonders among the nations, & publiÅ¿h my wonderous things among the Å¿trange people; then he read a note of the names of thoÅ¿e whom God had choÅ¿en for that legationOur Quakers have men every where. of whom himÅ¿elf was one; they were 26. (Sleydan Å¿aith two more) 7 were Å¿ent to OÅ¿nburge, 6 to CecÅ¿weld, 5 to Warendorp, 8 to Suzat; To them the King gave certain pieces of Gold, with this inÅ¿cription on the one Å¿ide, Æ²nleÅ¿s one be born by water and by the Spirit, he cannot enter into the Kingdom of Heaven. On the other Å¿ide, The Word was made fleÅ¿h, one God, one Faith, one BaptiÅ¿m. They were to preÅ¿ent that coin to every Town where their doctrine was not received, and leaveThe ApoÅ¿tles duÅ¿t more dreadful then their ãâã . it there for a TeÅ¿timony againÅ¿t them.

TheÅ¿e new ApoÅ¿tles went into the Cities where they were Å¿ent, crying in the Å¿treets that the people
Å¿hould repent, and join with them, elÅ¿e they Å¿hould Å¿hortly periÅ¿h. With that noiÅ¿e having raiÅ¿ed a tumult, they were apprehended & brought to the MagiÅ¿trates, before whom they Å¿pread a cloak upon the ground, and threw their coin upon it; Å¿aying, that they were Å¿ent by the Father to offer them peace, which if they refuÅ¿ed, they would leave that coin amongÅ¿t them as a pledge of Gods wrath againÅ¿t their ungratefulneÅ¿s and hardneÅ¿s of heart. That the time was come, foretold by the prophets, that the whole world Å¿hould follow righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s which God would work by their King, and when he had made righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s to raign over all the world, that then he Å¿hould give up the Kingdom unto his Father.

Being queÅ¿tioned by the MagiÅ¿trates, firÅ¿t with fair words, and after by tortures, about their faith, their converÅ¿ation, and the Å¿tate of the City of MunÅ¿ter, they anÅ¿wered that none in the world but they The trick of all Seduc â¢ rs., had the true Doctrine, which they were ready to Å¿eal with their blood CauÅ¿a, non poena, facit Martyrem.: that Å¿ince the ApoÅ¿tles time the word of God had not been purely preached, and no juÅ¿tice was in the earth: That there was four great Prophets; two good, David of Delft, and John of Leyden; and two bad, the Pope, and Luther; but Luther the worÅ¿t of the two True Religion more hated then fals by Seducers.. Being asked by what Scripture they could juÅ¿tifie their unjuÅ¿t diÅ¿poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing of Å¿o many good men from their houÅ¿es and goods, and making bold with their wives; They anÅ¿wered that the time was come foretold by ChriÅ¿t, that the meek Meek with a witneÅ¿s. Å¿hall inherit in the earth, That in the Å¿ame manner God had given
the goods of the Egyptians to the IÅ¿raelites, and among the goodsMad men reckon madly. they reckoned the wives; That they might lawfully take many wives upon condition they Å¿hould lye with them all till they were with childe; and when one was with child, they might take a new one in her Å¿tead. That they held women at 12 yearr of age, to be fit for husbands. That they put away barren women, or paÅ¿t child-bearing, and committed them to curators, as being good for nothing Poor encouragement for women â¢ o follow their precious ways..

As for the proviÅ¿ion of the Town, they Å¿aid that S. James Church was all full of Malt. That they had barly for two years, and many thouÅ¿and quarters of meal, and great Å¿tore of Bacon: A falÅ¿e relation, for Å¿oon after they fell to eating of dog â¢ and leather in MunÅ¿ter. They conÅ¿tantly affirmed that their King expected a great army out of Holland and Frize, which as Å¿oon as it was come, he would begin his expedition to Å¿ubdue the world, and kill all Kings for their perverÅ¿e adminiÅ¿tration of juÅ¿tice, and that they knew by revelation that their King of Sion would Å¿hortly be King of the whole earth. They perÅ¿iÅ¿ted in denying all MagiÅ¿trates but their own KingThey can down with their own., for which they were put to death, as enemies of all laws and order, and brands of Å¿edition; and there was an end of that ApoÅ¿tleÅ¿hip, that Å¿hould have preached a GoÅ¿pel of rebellion over all the world.

This legation was in October 1534. at which time MunÅ¿ter began to be Å¿hort of victuals: this occaÅ¿ioned a plot of Å¿ome of the Town to take the King, and Å¿end him bound to the BiÅ¿hop. The plot was
diÅ¿covered to the King, who thought it not Å¿afe to make the Authors known; only he committed the Town and himÅ¿elf to twelve truÅ¿ty Captains, to whom he divided a government in the air of Å¿everal Provinces, Å¿paring no Prince but the Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, whom he hoped to draw to his party; And with his Å¿mooth tongue he pacified the people, aÅ¿Å¿uring them that by EaÅ¿ter they Å¿hould certainly be delivered from all th â¢ ir enemies.

The princes of the Empire, Å¿eeing their danger, if this pretended King of the world came out and met with his confederates, met at Goblents as they had appointed, and took a courÅ¿e for the BiÅ¿hops help, and the Å¿traight beÅ¿ieging of the Town; and Å¿ent letters to the people of MunÅ¿ter to repreÅ¿ent them their fault and their danger; and that if they did not Å¿ubmit to their natural Prince, they Å¿hould draw all the forces of the Empire upon them. This was about the end of December, 1534.

They anÅ¿wered many words in commendation of their holy purpoÅ¿e, yet nothing to the purpoÅ¿e, and Å¿ent private letters beÅ¿ides to me Lantgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, to perÅ¿wade him to join with them, for the killing of all the wicked, and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing the Kingdom of the righteous in the world; and they Å¿ent him a book of that argument, whoÅ¿e title was, De reÅ¿titutione They Å¿hould have thought of it now and writ l â¢ Å¿s.: the Lantgrave cauÅ¿ed it to be anÅ¿wered by his Divines.

To draw towards the laÅ¿t Acts of that wild King, among the Prophets that were taken, one called Henry HilverÅ¿um was Å¿aved by the BiÅ¿hop, who after Å¿ome private conference with him, let him go;
And he returning to MunÅ¿ter, Å¿aid, that God had delivered him out of priÅ¿on by an Angel like Peter, and had Å¿ent him to announce to the King that he had given him three rich Cities, AmÅ¿terdam, Deventer, and WeÅ¿el, which Å¿hould Å¿hortly embrace his party: The King gladly received HilverÅ¿um, and made him one of his Court, and preÅ¿ently diÅ¿patched one James of Kemp to AmÅ¿terdam to bring that City to his obedience; which he was like to have done, having by his Å¿editious doctrine Å¿tirred the moÅ¿t part of the people againÅ¿t the MagiÅ¿trate, but that the Count of HochÅ¿tral, Governour of Holland, oppoÅ¿ed them with great wiÅ¿dom and with a high hand.

Soon after John of Leyden, hearing a report that many of his Å¿ect in Holland and Frize, were wandring in great Troops like Å¿heep having no Å¿hepherd, Å¿ent them one John Giles that had Å¿ome skill in war, with a great Å¿um of money, charging him that like another MoÅ¿es, he would be their leader in the wilderneÅ¿sVery â¢ rue there they were.; and bring them to Canaan, that is, to MunÅ¿ter. But when much time paÅ¿t, and he heard nothing of thoÅ¿e wandring IÅ¿raelites, nor of their MoÅ¿es, he Å¿ent the Prophet Henry HilverÅ¿um, and one John Nortell into Holland and Frize, to haÅ¿ten them, or raiÅ¿e new troops.

For that expedition he had loaden Henry HilverÅ¿um with Å¿o much Gold that he could Å¿carce go, wherefore he went no further than the BiÅ¿hops camp, where he Å¿tayed. John Nortell went as far as Deventer, and Å¿oon after returned without effect. HilverÅ¿um writ a Å¿enÅ¿ible letter to the people of

And to appeaÅ¿e the people, of whom many began to repentAll are not leÅ¿t that are gone â¢ ut of the way. of their error, and murmured againÅ¿t him, he made them a fine Å¿peech, Å¿aying that he would never have thought that they

Well, EaÅ¿ter came, and no help came; this put our Prophet King to his plunge; he Å¿hut himÅ¿elf up, faining to be Å¿ick, for Å¿ix days; then he came forth and Å¿aid to the people, that in his Å¿ickneÅ¿s God had

Sure if ever there was a falÅ¿e ChriÅ¿tAnother egregious in the WeÅ¿t Country. cf. Ellis his PÅ¿eudochriÅ¿tus 1650. this was one. Much did he rely upon the negotiation of Jo. Geles whom he dayly expected, beleiving as it was true, that he had a great party in Holland and Frize: And indeed Geles did all that the wit of man could do to raiÅ¿e troops for his King in thoÅ¿e Countries, which he put all in combuÅ¿tion, as we Å¿hall hear in the following Chapter. A few days after, famine increaÅ¿ing in the Town,

They had not held out Å¿o long, but that the Princes met at Coblents, could not agree about the contribution, and Å¿o the Å¿iege went but Å¿lowly on; but the Emperour made them meet again at Wormes in Aprill, where fifty thouÅ¿and crowns a month were granted to the BiÅ¿hop for five months, and it was ordered that after the taking of the Town, the innocent people Å¿hould be Å¿pared, and that all the good Citizens that were come out, or kept in by force, Å¿hould have reÅ¿tittuion of all their goods. means of two that fled out of the town, and guided OberÅ¿teyns Å¿ouldiers in the night, through the Town ditch, where the water was fordable: they Å¿caled the walls, killed the watches, and put the next Court of guard to the Å¿word. The BiÅ¿hop entred into the City the next day with 1500 horÅ¿e, and brought out the Å¿poil of the town from the Å¿ouldiers; the citizens that had yeilded were Å¿pared; but the fierce AnabaptiÅ¿ts that could never be tamed, and lay hid in Å¿everal holes, were Å¿ought out and killed; Å¿ome Souldiers having made bold with the handÅ¿omeÅ¿t women, were poiÅ¿oned with them, and found dead in their beds. The King and no King, was Å¿ent priÅ¿oner to a CaÅ¿tle four miles from MunÅ¿ter. He went thither Å¿omewhat faÅ¿ter then he would, being tyed to the tail of a galloping horÅ¿eHe had galloped enough, and was now at his journeys end., whereby his MajeÅ¿ty was no

div.p: THe AnabapiÅ¿ts that made themÅ¿elves maÅ¿ters of MunÅ¿ter, were deboyÅ¿hed tradeÅ¿men of Holland and Frize, and there during the troubles of MunÅ¿ter, the Å¿ame Å¿pirit was working with efficacy in the children of RebellionThe Divil a Ubiquatery.: They had like projects, but worÅ¿e Å¿ucceÅ¿s.

In Febr. 1534. Å¿ome of them raiÅ¿ing a Å¿edition at

March, letters came from the Emperor Charls the fifth, who was Lord of the Low-Countries, offering a free pardon to all of that Å¿ect, that would within a fortnight repent and confeÅ¿s their error, commanding withall that all perÅ¿ons perÅ¿iÅ¿ting in that Å¿ect Å¿hould be Å¿everely puniÅ¿ht according to the Laws. The next, he was commanded to Å¿tay up and wait for revelations, whereupon being very drowzie for want of reÅ¿t; he intreated the apparitions he might reÅ¿t that night; Å¿o he had liberty: but going up Å¿tairs, a voice in him, willed him to go down, Å¿o was enjoyned to Å¿tay up; and having waited a Å¿hort time, he could not refrain from reÅ¿t; then was he perÅ¿waded to go againÅ¿t the Spirit, but in going, it commanded him to go into the Å¿hop; having Å¿taid there about halfe an hour, he moved to go up; but going, a voice Å¿pake behind, to return; then was he commanded by that in him, to lie down and humble himÅ¿elf, for he had blaÅ¿phemed: then he heard another voice, Nicodemus the betrayer of ChriÅ¿t in the night is in thee; at which he was extremely troubled; Å¿o lying about an hour upon the ground, he was moved to riÅ¿e; but riÅ¿ing, commanded to lie down again; anon riÅ¿ing, commanded again to lie Å¿till, and Å¿o diverÅ¿e times, in the end he was raiÅ¿ed on his feet.

Sau's errand p. 29.30.WHo gives this account of himÅ¿elf, that he was born at ArdiÅ¿law two miles from Wakefield in YorkÅ¿hire, where he lived untill he was married, then went into Wakefield pariÅ¿h, a Husband-man, a Souldier betwixt eight and nine years, and of turning Quaker gives this account, that he was at the Plow meditating on the things of God, and Å¿uddenly he heard a voice Å¿aying get thee out from thy Kindred and Fathers HouÅ¿e and had a promiÅ¿e given in with it that God would be with him; whereat he did exceedingly rejoyce, and when he came home he gave up his eÅ¿tate, caÅ¿t out his mony, but not

If they did it to the viÅ¿ible they were to blame, but if to the inviÅ¿ible, that worÅ¿hip is due to me according to my meaÅ¿ure as was due to ChriÅ¿t. Upon the fourth of December report was made to the houÅ¿e, & on the fixth he was brought to the Commons-bar where having his Examination taken before the Committee read unto him, and asked whether things were thus, he anÅ¿wered yea, and denied not any part thereof. After 8 or 9 dayes debate on the 16 of December, it being carried that the queÅ¿tion for his death Å¿hould not be put, the houÅ¿e Voted his puniÅ¿hment, that upon the 18th. of December he Å¿tand in the pillory two hours in the new palace yard with a paper of his crime on his breaÅ¿t,
